rafekettler.com

My thoughts on programming and technology

  • Blog
  • About me
  • Magic Methods Guide

At rafekettler.com, I write about interesting things that I encounter in programming, technology, and the rest of the world. Some articles may be tutorial in nature, others expository, and some editorial. Mainly, I just try to share things that I encounter that I feel need sharing.

I do most of my coding in Python and C. I use PHP as well, but I have to say it's less than enjoyable. I'm actively involved in a few projects/sites, including fixing bugs in Python, the Python Magic Methods Guide, and Stack Overflow. I also read a few newsgroups: comp.lang.python, comp.lang.c, comp.emacs, and a few others (I don't post often, though), and I sometimes post on the programming subreddit.

At the moment, I'm preparing to enter computer science school. I'm still not quite sure what I want to do going forward, but I know programming will be a big part of that.

My topics of interest include:

  • Functional programming
  • Optimization and efficiency
  • Source/version control (I'm partial to git)
  • Interesting and unusual syntax (e.g. decorators in Python)

Tools that I use (and enjoy):

  • Python
  • GNU Emacs
  • C and gcc
  • Linux (Fedora is my distro of choice)
  • git
  • GitHub -- you can view my projects and profile here
  • markdown (blog, Magic Methods Guide, reddit, Stack Overflow, github, etc.)

I try to update the site weekly (or more often if I can), but some weeks may be more or less busy depending on what I'm doing. I have plenty of free time, so if you need someone to contribute to a project (and it's either in Python, C, or in an environment with enough tolerance for error), I'd be happy and honored to help. I benefit immensely on a day to day basis from open-source software, and the least I can do is give back.

If you want to get in touch, find me on Facebook, Github, or Skype (be sure to mention programming or something, or else I'll surely ignore any requests), or leave a comment.

Here's the legal notice: all of the code I put on this site ("the Software") is licensed under an MIT license, provided that I've written it myself (if I take it from somewhere else, I'll be sure to say so). So, if you find a snippet on this site useful and want to use it in your project, a personal experiment or script, or at work, feel free to do so without any restriction, so long as you acknowledge me.
